history.content: Long story short, lecture waitlists usually don't matter - more on this in a bit. It's your position in the discussion section that matters. If you know that you're really, really high up on the discussion waitlist (i.e. #1, maybe #2), you can expect (heh CS 70) 2-3 people to drop anyways, so you should be fine. However, if you don't know, seeing as how CalCentral does not display discussion waitlist position, it's better to switch. In our current enrollment system, one has to enroll in lecture and discussion simultaneously, so if you can't get into a discussion, you're not getting into lecture either.

children.subject:
Yes. "one has to enroll in lecture and discussion simultaneously".

p.s. you should really search for past posts for this kind of waitlist logistics information; regurgitating all this is rather bothersome
I did, but apologies if this sounded redundant. I thought my situation was unique in that in the past, I was unable to re-add the class altogether.
In any case, thanks again for taking the time to respond.

It's ok - I thought you hadn't taken the time - thanks for doing so! You can look up waitlist lengths on both classes.berkeley.edu and the Oracle system, accessible at schedule.berkeley.edu. In theory, when you drop from the lecture waitlist, a spot should open up on it, so you should be able to re-add.

The last time I tried to do this with another class, I was unable to readd the class because it seemed as though the waitlist itself was full and not accepting anymore "adds" of the class. This was during last semester's phase II period. I currently see open sections with up to 20+ open seats without any waitlist; if I try to add after dropping, assuming I am able to add, will I be placed back on the lecture waitlist even if the discussion section I enroll in is supposedly open?
how do you tell what position you are on the waitlist? i only see how many people are on the waitlist and how many waitlist spots are still open

history.content: As an undeclared CS major looking to get into CS70, I noticed new sections opened up for enrollment. Being currently 23rd on the lecture waitlist, and waitlisted for a full discussion section with 10 students on the waitlist, was wondering if I would be helping or hurting my chances of getting in by dropping the class, and trying to enroll in the open sections. I am still a bit unclear as to how prioritization for these seats works.
history.subject: CS 70 Waitlist/New Open Sections
